text: Kingdom of Saudi Arabia KINGDOM OF SAUDI ARABIA
Ministry of Environment, Water and Agriculture
Kingdom of Saudi Arabia Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, Jumada al-Awwal 1439 AH - January 2018 AD
The royal shamrock, the son’s head, is drawn to the skin of Abd al-Azal al-Ath, Hafzaallah
The Crown Prince, Deputy Prime Minister, Minister of Defense, and Chairman of the Council of Economic and Development Affairs

I would like - first of all - to express my deepest thanks and gratitude to the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud, and to His Royal Highness Prince Mohammed bin Salman bin Abdulaziz, Crown Prince, Deputy Prime Minister, Minister of Defense and Chairman of the Council of Economic and Development Affairs, may God protect them both. ; Due to the issuance of the Council of Ministers’ decision on the sixth of Jumada Al-Awwal of the year 1439 AH approving the National Water Strategy 2030, which came based on the vision of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia 2030; To serve as an integrated water plan that lays the foundations for a system that develops infrastructure and addresses all major challenges in the water and sanitation sector in the Kingdom. This is done by establishing comprehensive structural institutional frameworks, providing enabling mechanisms and drawing effective implementation plans. This strategy provides programs and initiatives aimed at developing and preserving water sources, reducing water waste, and benefiting from treated wastewater, and provides a model for an investment partnership with the private sector to provide better service in the production, transportation, distribution, treatment, and reuse sectors. Implementing and activating the programs of this strategy will contribute to: God willing, we will reduce the demand for water and develop and preserve water resources, which will have a profound impact on achieving water security, contributing to sustainable development, enhancing the localization of water technologies, and raising the level of positive contribution to the national economy. I look forward to everyone’s cooperation in implementing the programs of the National Water Strategy in order to achieve the aspirations of the wise leadership - may God support it - and the requirements of sustainable development.
Minister of Environment, Water and Agriculture Eng. Abdul Rahman bin Abdul Mohsen Al-Fadhli

Water demand associated with irrigation does not usually include livestock and aquaculture requirements, as requirements for these areas are small and difficult to estimate.
Water needs in the agricultural sector
The volume of water stored in above-ground tanks within the municipal supply system (production - transportation - distribution) divided by the average demand in the municipal sector for each day.
Total number of residents connected to the sewage network/total population x 100.
Total number of resident population connected to the water network/total population x 100.
Divide the total volume of treated water/total volume of wastewater collected
Total cost of water and wastewater services in the municipal sector/total volume of water supplied and wastewater collected.
Quantities of water consumed inside and outside homes in families for multiple uses, such as drinking, cooking, hygiene, bathing, and irrigation.
Water needs of the municipal/residential sector
Quantities of water used by industries that supply water through independent networks, such as: MODON, the Royal Commission for Jubail, Yanbu, and Saudi Aramco.
Water needs of the industrial sector
Total full load at the outlet of the water production plant.
The ratio between the amounts of water consumed to irrigate a specific crop and the total amounts of water available through the irrigation process.

Quantities of water consumed by all customers connected to municipal water distribution systems, including domestic, industrial, commercial, and governmental demand, excluding the water needs of the industrial sector.
Water needs of the urban sector

The difference between “net production” (i.e. the volume of water available in a water distribution network) and water available to consumers (i.e. the volume of water “lost”) as a proportion of net production. These include technical losses (such as leakage, evaporation) and commercial losses (illegal connection and unbilled consumption).
Percentage of collected and treated wastewater out of total municipal water produced.
Percentage of the volume of treated wastewater used in economic activities out of the total volume of treated water used in underground storage recovery plans.
Water from which there is no income minus any legal unbilled consumption (i.e. billed and unbilled water).
The cost consumers spend on water as a proportion of their total spending in the same period.

Water is one of the most important axes of economic and social development. As it is essential for meeting human needs, managing the environment, and ensuring the sustainability of economic development, and despite the importance of water, the Kingdom faces great challenges due to the unsustainable use of water resources, as well as the limited stock of non-renewable groundwater, which is witnessing rapid depletion, and under the circumstances In the arid climate, renewable water is extremely scarce. In addition, the high demand for water in the agricultural sector exacerbates the problem of water scarcity in the Kingdom. The government also bears a high cost for water production and sanitation services in the urban sector. However, service levels are still below The optimal level, and the sector also suffers from inappropriate institutional conditions and governance mechanisms. Within this framework, the Ministry of Environment, Water and Agriculture undertook the task of developing a unified frame of reference for the water sector, which includes a comprehensive water strategy, and works to integrate trends, policies, legislation, and practices in the water sector at the national level, with the main goal of confronting the main challenges and restructuring the sector. . The scope of work to prepare the framework includes many elements, including engaging stakeholders, assessing the current situation of the sector across a range of dimensions, such as: water demand, water resources, sector operations, enabling factors, identifying the nature and size of gaps between supply and demand, in addition to Economics of the sector under different scenarios. The National Water Strategy document presents the strategy’s vision and objectives, as well as supply and demand strategies and operational processes. The strategy also includes mechanisms for developing institutional frameworks and other enabling tools, financial projections, and financing models. In addition, an implementation plan and performance management framework have been included to ensure the implementation of the initiatives that The strategy recommends them in an effective and timely manner.
The Kingdom's National Water Strategy 2030 was prepared using an 11-step approach, which is divided into:
It is divided into three stages: (1) Evaluation of the current situation. (2) Determine the strategy. (3) Implementation planning.
Preparing the implementation plan and monitoring and evaluation framework
8 Determine the institutional framework and other strategic incentives
Preparing the vision and goals of the water sector
5 Summarize the sustainability and challenges of the water sector
Review and evaluate water resources and supply systems
Review the evaluation of current sector incentives
Review the strategic framework and national objectives

A comprehensive framework was adopted to prepare the strategy and was used during the three stages. This framework consists of three main elements: Objectives: Formulating the objectives of the water and sanitation sector in five dimensions: security of supply, quality and excellence in customer service, environmental sustainability, and economic sustainability. And cost management. Components: Assessing water demand, developing potential demand management measures, determining the optimal supply composition in light of the resources available in the Kingdom, and evaluating the supply chain. Enablers: Performance management mechanisms to ensure the desired efficiency is achieved, and also includes the appropriate institutional framework that clearly indicates the delegation to the various bodies charged with policy-making and planning, water resources management, legislation, and providing service to the consumer. In addition, the possibilities include the possibility of private sector participation and the accompanying necessary policies, legal and legislative frameworks. Furthermore, the third component takes into account organizational and human capabilities, procedures, technology, systems, financial requirements, financing, marketing, and localization in the sector.

During the preparation of this strategy, the development team reviewed relevant studies and reports prepared by stakeholders in the water sector to ensure the benefit of the latest available research and data. An assessment of the current situation of the water sector in the Kingdom was conducted by adopting an integrated framework that includes many contents covering critical aspects of the sector. The assessment also relied on many previous studies, personal interviews with key stakeholders, and standard comparison with international models. Comparison of previous studies has revealed a consensus on the need to rationalize water demand, especially in the agricultural sector. The studies also stress the importance of adopting an integrated approach to developing, directing and diversifying national and local water supply sources, improving operations in the sector, and conducting a comprehensive assessment of the institutional framework and mechanisms. Possible governance, and considering the possibility of private sector participation in providing the service. The Kingdom has a limited reserve of non-renewable groundwater that can be exploited, as well as low recharge rates, due to arid climatic conditions. Water requirements in the Kingdom (which were estimated in 2015 at about 24.8 billion cubic meters) are witnessing a constant annual increase of 7%, noting that the agricultural sector is the largest consumer of water in the Kingdom, with 84% of the total water demand, and this reflects the use of water in The agricultural sector is an environmental challenge; Due to its dependence on non-renewable resources, which represent 90% of the total water supplied to the sector. The high use of water in the agricultural sector is due to gaps in water sector policies, legislation, and general deficiencies in use, as fodder alone consumes 79% of the water requirements in the agricultural sector, and irrigation efficiency is currently 50% compared to more than 75%. According to global best practices, and in light of current rates of consumption, some regions in the Kingdom may face a depletion of reserve stocks during the next twelve years, and this calls for immediate action to be taken to solve this problem. Despite water scarcity, treated wastewater is underutilized due to limited infrastructure, challenges in accepting the use of this water in some areas, and limited legislative oversight and pricing incentives. Water consumption in the urban sector provides each individual with many opportunities for improvement, and this can be achieved by reducing water losses in the network (estimated at more than 25% in different regions), within buildings, and by setting price indicators and incentives for water conservation. In light of the high dependence on water desalination (60% of the total water supply in the urban sector), in addition to the current subsidies, this sector imposes many burdens on

The national economy, and the relatively high unit cost of production increases due to the high transportation costs by pumping water from the coast to the interior. The sector also depends - to a large extent - on fuel. Fuel consumption in water desalination represents more than 25% of the volume of national fuel production. In addition, desalination leaves a large environmental footprint, due to the means of disposing of salt and clay deposits, as well as greenhouse gas emissions. Operational challenges and those related to the quality of services must also be dealt with efficiently, as there is a need to expand the coverage of the water and sanitation network, in addition to reducing the high losses in distribution networks related to technical problems. Homes suffer from an irregular supply, which requires them to rely on water tankers, which are relatively expensive. On the other hand, the infrastructure has become somewhat outdated, and mega projects are being delayed due to financing challenges. The billing and collection process is low across the Kingdom, which exacerbates the problem of already low cost recovery levels in this sector. Thus, low cost recovery levels contribute to reducing the incentives of service providers to improve the quality of services. In addition, there is a need to fill a number of Gaps related to institutional capacity, human capital, technologies, and processes, which contribute to enabling the sector to align with global standards. The government has launched several initiatives to reform the water sector in accordance with royal decrees issued to encourage private sector involvement, but the Ministry of Environment, Water and Agriculture continues to play an essential role across all functions and steps in the water sector chain, and there is a limited focus on developing water policies and secondary governance. Due to the extensive intervention of the Ministry of Environment, Water and Agriculture in providing the service. There is limited oversight of the economics and resources of the sector, which may hamper the management of water resources at both the national and local levels. The current legislative and legal framework is insufficient and does not enable effective governance, given that the water sector is still subject to the Water Regulations issued in 1980. There is no independent legislative body for the full value chain of operations, and no licensing plans are being implemented regarding water resources management. While other legislation is either unavailable or not adequately implemented, commercial relationships and agreements between the main stakeholders in the provision of water services are themselves either unavailable or insufficient, affecting transparency, accountability and governance. These structural issues have limited private sector participation in the water sector, as private sector participation is mainly limited to water production. The National Water Strategy 2030 aims to address all major challenges, benefit from previous and ongoing studies, and reform the water and sanitation sector to ensure sustainable development of water resources in the Kingdom, while providing relevant services.
